title: 109_s1519
content: The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005, also known as the Small Business Act, is amended to include a new section 37 regarding agency restructuring or termination of facility use. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 is amended to include definitions for terms like agency, qualifying termination or restructuring, restructuring, small governmental jurisdiction, and State. The act also outlines that a qualifying termination or restructuring involves the net loss of at least 1,000 jobs in any State. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 requires agencies and other authorized entities to conduct an economic analysis before finalizing any qualified termination or restructuring. This analysis must assess the impact on small businesses and small governmental jurisdictions. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 mandates a detailed economic analysis by authorized entities before finalizing any qualifying termination or restructuring. This analysis includes assessing the impact on small business concerns and small governmental jurisdictions, efforts to minimize adverse economic effects, and exploring alternative termination options. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 requires a detailed economic analysis before finalizing any termination or restructuring, including assessing impact on small businesses and governmental jurisdictions, exploring alternatives, and conducting cost-benefit analysis in affected states. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 mandates a cost-benefit analysis for any proposed termination or restructuring exceeding $100,000,000 in economic impact in a State. The analysis includes evaluating costs and benefits to small businesses and governmental jurisdictions, providing alternative options, and summarizing the findings. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 requires a cost-benefit analysis for proposed terminations or restructurings exceeding $100,000,000 in economic impact in a State. The analysis evaluates costs and benefits to small businesses and governmental jurisdictions, provides alternative options, and ensures transparency through measures like incorporating an executive summary and detailing assumptions. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 mandates a cost-benefit analysis for terminations or restructurings exceeding $100,000,000 in economic impact. The analysis includes an executive summary, assumptions, data sources, model documentation, and sensitivity analyses. Agencies must publish a draft economic analysis on their website 180 days before final action. The Small Business Economic Impact Analysis Act of 2005 requires agencies to publish a draft economic analysis on their website and provide notice in the Federal Register with a 60-day comment period. After considering comments, a final economic analysis must be published on the website and in the Federal Register. The agency must submit the final economic analysis to the Comptroller General of the United States for review within 90 days, who will then publish a report on the sufficiency of the analysis. The Comptroller General of the United States will analyze and report on the sufficiency of the final economic analysis submitted by an agency or entity. If the analysis is deemed insufficient, the procedures must be repeated. Final action on a termination or restructuring cannot be taken until a satisfactory review is received. Small businesses or governmental jurisdictions affected by the termination or restructuring can file for judicial review within 90 days of the final economic analysis notice being published. Small businesses or governmental jurisdictions affected by a qualifying termination or restructuring can file a petition for judicial review with the Court of Appeals for expedited review. The review is limited to determining if the agency action was arbitrary, capricious, or not in accordance with the law, and if the economic analysis was insufficient. The requirements apply to any termination or restructuring where final action has not occurred.
